column2: CHAPTER XXIX
column3: CHAPTER twenty nine

column2: IN WHICH CASSANDRA VISITS DAVID THRYNG'S ANCESTORS
column3: IN WHICH CASSANDRA VISITS DAVID THRYNG'S ANCESTORS

column2: It was a pleasant morning in London, with as clear a sky as is ever permitted to that great city.
column3: It was a pleasant morning in London, with as clear a sky as is ever permitted to that great city.

column2: Cassandra had placed her little son in the middle of a huge bed which nearly filled the small room she had been given in a hotel, recommended to her by Betty Towers as one where "nice ladies travelling alone" could stop.
column3: Cassandra had placed her little son in the middle of a huge bed which nearly filled the small room she had been given in a hotel, recommended to her by Betty Towers as one where "nice ladies travelling alone" could stop.

column2: The child was dressed in a fresh white coat, and Cassandra had much ado to keep him clean.
column3: The child was dressed in a fresh white coat, and Cassandra had much ado to keep him clean.

column2: She heaped him about with pillows and bedclothing to make a nest for him, and gave him a spoon and a drinking cup for entertainment, while she arranged her own toilet before a cloudy mirror by a slant ray of daylight that managed to sift through the heavy draperies and lace curtains that obscured the one high, narrow window of her room.
column3: She heaped him about with pillows and bedclothing to make a nest for him, and gave him a spoon and a drinking cup for entertainment, while she arranged her own toilet before a cloudy mirror by a slant ray of daylight that managed to sift through the heavy draperies and lace curtains that obscured the one high, narrow window of her room.

column2: She had tried to put them one side that she might look out when she awoke, but she could see only chimney-pots and grimy, irregularly tiled roofs.
column3: She had tried to put them one side that she might look out when she awoke, but she could see only chimney pots and grimy, irregularly tiled roofs.

column2: A narrow opening at the top of the window let in a little air; still she felt smothered, and tried to raise the lower sash, but could not move it.
column3: A narrow opening at the top of the window let in a little air; still she felt smothered, and tried to raise the lower sash, but could not move it.

column2: She thought of the books she had read about great cities, and how some people had to live in places like this always; and her heart filled with a large pity for them.
column3: She thought of the books she had read about great cities, and how some people had to live in places like this always; and her heart filled with a large pity for them.

column2: Here only a small triangle of blue sky could be seen--not a tree, not a bit of earth--and in the small room all those heavy furnishings closed around her, dark red, stuffy, and greasy with London smoke.
column3: Here only a small triangle of blue sky could be seen-not a tree, not a bit of earth-and in the small room all those heavy furnishings closed around her, dark red, stuffy, and greasy with London smoke.

column2: She could not touch them without blackening her hands, nor let her baby sit on the floor for the dirt he wiped up on his clothing as he rolled and kicked about.
column3: She could not touch them without blackening her hands, nor let her baby sit on the floor for the dirt he wiped up on his clothing as he rolled and kicked about.

column2: The room seemed to sway and tip as the ship had done, and there was a continuous sound as of thunder, a strange undercurrent that seemed to her strained nerves like the moaning of the lost souls of all the ages, who had lived and toiled and smothered in this monstrous and terrible city.
column3: The room seemed to sway and tip as the ship had done, and there was a continuous sound as of thunder, a strange undercurrent that seemed to her strained nerves like the moaning of the lost souls of all the ages, who had lived and toiled and smothered in this monstrous and terrible city.

column2: Ah, she must get out of it.
column3: Ah, she must get out of it.

column2: She must hurry--hurry and find David.
column3: She must hurry-hurry and find David.

column2: He would be glad to see his little son.
column3: He would be glad to see his little son.

column2: He would take him in his arms.
column3: He would take him in his arms.

column2: He would hold them both to his heart.
column3: He would hold them both to his heart.

column2: She would see him smile again and look in his eyes, and all this foreboding would cease, and the woful sounds die out of the air and become only the natural roar of the activities and traffic of a great city.
column3: She would see him smile again and look in his eyes, and all this foreboding would cease, and the woful sounds die out of the air and become only the natural roar of the activities and traffic of a great city.

column2: She must get used to all this, and not expect to find all the world like her own sunny mountains.
column3: She must get used to all this, and not expect to find all the world like her own sunny mountains.

column2: The bishop's careful little wife had tried to explain to her how to meet her new experiences.
column3: The bishop's careful little wife had tried to explain to her how to meet her new experiences.

column2: She was to go nowhere alone, without taking a cab, and never start out on foot, carrying her baby in her arms, as she might do at home.
column3: She was to go nowhere alone, without taking a cab, and never start out on foot, carrying her baby in her arms, as she might do at home.

column2: She had given her written instructions how to conduct herself under all ordinary circumstances, at her hotel or on the street--how to ring for a servant, order her meals, or call a cab.
column3: She had given her written instructions how to conduct herself under all ordinary circumstances, at her hotel or on the street-how to ring for a servant, order her meals, or call a cab.

column2: Now, standing before her mirror, Cassandra essayed to arrange her hair as she had seen other young women wear theirs, but she thought the new way looked untidy, and she took it all down and rearranged it as she was used to wear it.
column3: Now, standing before her mirror, Cassandra essayed to arrange her hair as she had seen other young women wear theirs, but she thought the new way looked untidy, and she took it all down and rearranged it as she was used to wear it.

column2: David would not mind if she did not do her hair as others did, he would be so glad to see her and his little son.
column3: David would not mind if she did not do her hair as others did, he would be so glad to see her and his little son.

column2: Ah, the comfort of that little son!
column3: Ah, the comfort of that little son!

column2: She leaned over the bed, half dressed as she was, and murmured pretty cooing phrases, kissing and cuddling him to contented laughter.
column3: She leaned over the bed, half dressed as she was, and murmured pretty cooing phrases, kissing and cuddling him to contented laughter.

column2: Betty Towers had procured clothing for her--a modest supply--using her own good taste, and not disguising Cassandra's natural grace and dignity by a too-close adherence to the prevailing mode.
column3: Betty Towers had procured clothing for her-a modest supply-using her own good taste, and not disguising Cassandra's natural grace and dignity by a too close adherence to the prevailing mode.

column2: There were a blue travelling gown and jacket, and a toque of the same color with a white wing; a soft clinging black silk, made with girlish simplicity which admirably became her, and a wide, flexible brimmed hat with a single heavy plume taken from Betty's own hat of the last winter.
column3: There were a blue travelling gown and jacket, and a toque of the same color with a white wing; a soft clinging black silk, made with girlish simplicity which admirably became her, and a wide, flexible brimmed hat with a single heavy plume taken from Betty's own hat of the last winter.

column2: Cassandra stood a long moment before the two gowns.
column3: Cassandra stood a long moment before the two gowns.

column2: She desired to don the silk, but Betty had told her always to wear the blue in the morning, so at last she obeyed her kind adviser.
column3: She desired to don the silk, but Betty had told her always to wear the blue in the morning, so at last she obeyed her kind adviser.

column2: While waiting with her baby in her arms for the hotel boy to call her cab, she observed another lady, young and graceful, enter a cab, and a maid following her wearing a pretty cap, and carrying a child.
column3: While waiting with her baby in her arms for the hotel boy to call her cab, she observed another lady, young and graceful, enter a cab, and a maid following her wearing a pretty cap, and carrying a child.

column2: Eager, for David's sake, to draw no adverse comment upon herself, she took note of everything.
column3: Eager, for David's sake, to draw no adverse comment upon herself, she took note of everything.

column2: Ought she then to arrive attended by a maid, carrying her baby?
column3: Ought she then to arrive attended by a maid, carrying her baby?

column2: But David would know she did not need one; bringing him his little son in her own arms, what would he care for anything more?
column3: But David would know she did not need one; bringing him his little son in her own arms, what would he care for anything more?

column2: So the address was given the cabman, and they were rattled away over the rough paving, a long, lonely ride through the wonderful city--so many miles of houses and splendid buildings, of gardens and monuments.
column3: So the address was given the cabman, and they were rattled away over the rough paving, a long, lonely ride through the wonderful city-so many miles of houses and splendid buildings, of gardens and monuments.

column2: Strangely, the people of _Vanity Fair_ leaped out of the book she had read, and walked the streets or dashed by her in cabs--albeit in modern dress.
column3: Strangely, the people of underscore Vanity Fair underscore leaped out of the book she had read, and walked the streets or dashed by her in cabs-albeit in modern dress.

column2: The soldiers--the guardsmen--the liveried lackeys--the errand boys--all were there, and the ladies in fine carriages.
column3: The soldiers-the guardsmen-the liveried lackeys-the errand boys-all were there, and the ladies in fine carriages.

column2: There were the nursemaids--the babies--the beggars--the ragged urchins and the venders of the street, with their raucous cries rending the air.
column3: There were the nursemaids-the babies-the beggars-the ragged urchins and the venders of the street, with their raucous cries rending the air.

column2: Her brain whirled, and a new feeling to which she had hitherto been blessedly a stranger crept over her, a feeling of fear.
column3: Her brain whirled, and a new feeling to which she had hitherto been blessedly a stranger crept over her, a feeling of fear.

column2: As the great two-story coaches and trams thundered by, she clasped her baby closer, until he looked up in her face with round-eyed wonder and put up his lip in pitiful protest.
column3: As the great two story coaches and trams thundered by, she clasped her baby closer, until he looked up in her face with round eyed wonder and put up his lip in pitiful protest.

column2: She soothed and comforted him until her panic passed, and when, at last, they stopped before a great house built in on either side by other houses, with wide steps of stone descending directly upon the street, she had regained a measure of composure.
column3: She soothed and comforted him until her panic passed, and when, at last, they stopped before a great house built in on either side by other houses, with wide steps of stone descending directly upon the street, she had regained a measure of composure.

column2: She was assured by the cabman, leaning respectfully down to her with his cap in his hand, that this was "the 'ouse, ma'm," and should he wait?
column3: She was assured by the cabman, leaning respectfully down to her with his cap in his hand, that this was "the 'ouse, ma'm," and should he wait?

column2: Wait," cried Cassandra.
column3: Wait," cried Cassandra.

column2: What if David were not there!
column3: What if David were not there!

column2: And of course, he might be out.
column3: And of course, he might be out.

column2: Then they were swallowed up in the dark interior.
column3: Then they were swallowed up in the dark interior.

column2: She was admitted to a hall that seemed to her empty and vast, by a little old man in livery.
column3: She was admitted to a hall that seemed to her empty and vast, by a little old man in livery.

column2: For a moment, bewildered, she could hardly understand what he was saying to her.
column3: For a moment, bewildered, she could hardly understand what he was saying to her.

column2: 'Er ladyship's at 'er country 'ome and the 'ouse closed.
column3: 'Er ladyship's at 'er country 'o m e and the 'ouse closed.

column2: Although dazed and baffled, Cassandra betrayed no sign of the tumult within, and the little old man stood before her hesitating, his curiosity piqued into a determination to discover her business and identity.
column3: Although dazed and baffled, Cassandra betrayed no sign of the tumult within, and the little old man stood before her hesitating, his curiosity piqued into a determination to discover her business and identity.

column2: Her gravity and silence gave her a poise and dignity that allayed suspicion, but he and his old wife liked diversion, and a spice of gossip lightened the monotony of their lives, so he waited, then coughed behind his hand.
column3: Her gravity and silence gave her a poise and dignity that allayed suspicion, but he and his old wife liked diversion, and a spice of gossip lightened the monotony of their lives, so he waited, then coughed behind his hand.

column2: Yes, 'er ladyship and Lady Laura are at their country 'ome now, ma'm. Maybe you came to see the 'ouse, ma'm?
column3: Yes, 'er ladyship and Lady Laura are at their country 'o m e now, ma'm. Maybe you came to see the 'ouse, ma'm?

column2: No, it was not the house--it was-- Again she waited, not knowing how to introduce her husband's name.
column3: No, it was not the house-it was- Again she waited, not knowing how to introduce her husband's name.

column2: A mystery!
column3: A mystery!

column2: A visitor at this hour, and seemingly a lady, yet with a baby in her arms, and alone, and not to see the house.
column3: A visitor at this hour, and seemingly a lady, yet with a baby in her arms, and alone, and not to see the house.

column2: Again he coughed behind his hand.
column3: Again he coughed behind his hand.

column2: A many do come to see the 'ouse, ma'm, with a permit from 'is lordship, ma'm. 'E's not 'ere now, but strangers are halways welcome--to the gallery, ma'm.
column3: A many do come to see the 'ouse, ma'm, with a permit from 'is lordship, ma'm. 'E's not 'ere now, but strangers are halways welcome-to the gallery, ma'm.

column2: Yes, I'm a stranger. She caught at the word.
column3: Yes, I'm a stranger. She caught at the word.

column2: Seized by an inward terror of the small eyes fixed curiously on her, she intuitively shrank from betraying her identity, and the old servant had told her what she needed to know.
column3: Seized by an inward terror of the small eyes fixed curiously on her, she intuitively shrank from betraying her identity, and the old servant had told her what she needed to know.

column2: Of course her husband was "his lordship," over here.

column2: I am from America, and I would like to see the gallery. She must do so to give a pretext for having come to visit an empty house.
column3: I am from America, and I would like to see the gallery. She must do so to give a pretext for having come to visit an empty house.

column2: For all of the warm August sun shining without, a chill struck to her bones as they passed through the vast, closed rooms.
column3: For all of the warm August sun shining without, a chill struck to her bones as they passed through the vast, closed rooms.

column2: She held her now sleeping baby close to her breast as she followed the old man about from picture to picture.
column3: She held her now sleeping baby close to her breast as she followed the old man about from picture to picture.

column2: Yes, a many do come 'ere--especially hartists--to see this gallery. They say as 'ow 'is lordship wouldn't take a thousand pounds for this one, ma'm. column2: A Vandyke--and worth it's weight in gold."

column2: She drew a deep breath and looked down the length of the long gallery.

column2: Everything was being impressed upon her mind as upon sensitized paper.

column3: She followed slowly in the old man's wake, never opening her lips until they had made the circuit and were again standing before the portrait of the fair haired youth.

column2: Then, roused suddenly by a direct question, she responded.
column3: Then, roused suddenly by a direct question, she responded.

column2: The old servant was saying: "You 'aven't 'appened to meet a Samuel Cutter in America, 'ave you?
column3: The old servant was saying: "You 'aven't 'appened to meet a Samuel Cutter in America, 'ave you?

column2: 'E's our son.
column3: 'E's our son.

column2: England was too slow for 'im. Young men aren't like old ones; they wants hadventure, and they gets it. That's 'ow so many of 'em joins the harmy and gets killed like 'is lordship's two sons, and young Lord Thryng's brother as would 'ave been 'is lordship, if 'e' ad lived.

column2: You 'aven't 'appened to know a Samuel Cutter over there?
column3: You 'aven't 'appened to know a Samuel Cutter over there?

column2: I live a long way from Canada."
column3: I live a long way from Canada."

column2: About 'ow far do you think, ma'm?

column2: It takes three or four days to get there from my home.

column2: England may be a small place, but she 'as tremendous big possessions." He felt it all belonged to England, and spoke with swelling pride as his short legs carried him toward the door. There again he paused.

column3: If you'd ever seen 'im, you'd think 'e'd dressed up in velvet and lace and stood for it.

column2: Is he at their country home also? Cassandra asked.

column2: She must get out of that house and hear no more.

column2: She felt herself moving in an unreal world.

column2: David--her David--she had not come to him after all; she had come to an empty place.
column3: David-her David-she had not come to him after all; she had come to an empty place.

column3: She knelt and threw her arms about her little son, encircling his head and his feet.

column2: She neither wept nor prayed; and the red spot burned against the creamy whiteness of her skin.
column3: She neither wept nor prayed; and the red spot burned against the creamy whiteness of her skin.

column2: She was not thinking, only looking, seeing into the past and down the long vista of her future.
column3: She was not thinking, only looking, seeing into the past and down the long vista of her future.

column2: Pictures came to her--pictures of her girlhood--her dim aspirations--her melancholy-eyed father--his hilltop--and beloved, sunlit mountains.
column3: Pictures came to her-pictures of her girlhood-her dim aspirations-her melancholy eyed father-his hilltop-and beloved, sunlit mountains.

column2: In the radiance of the spring, she saw them, and in the glory of the autumn; she breathed the fragrance of the pines in winter and heard the soft patter of summer rains on widespreading leaves.
column3: In the radiance of the spring, she saw them, and in the glory of the autumn; she breathed the fragrance of the pines in winter and heard the soft patter of summer rains on widespreading leaves.

column2: She saw David walking at her side, and heard his laugh, sun-bright and glorious he seemed, her Phoebus Apollo--the father of her little son.
column3: She saw David walking at her side, and heard his laugh, sun bright and glorious he seemed, her Phoebus Apollo-the father of her little son.

column2: She saw the terrible sea which she had crossed to come to him--the white-crested waves, with turquoise lights and indigo depths, shifting and sliding unceasingly where all the world seemed swallowed in space, and the huge steamship so small a thing in the vast and perilous deep; and now--now she was here.
column3: She saw the terrible sea which she had crossed to come to him-the white crested waves, with turquoise lights and indigo depths, shifting and sliding unceasingly where all the world seemed swallowed in space, and the huge steamship so small a thing in the vast and perilous deep; and now-now she was here.

column2: What was she?
column3: What was she?

column2: What was life?

column2: She had tried to find him, her David, and had been shown the dead, and the glory of the dead--all past and gone--her David's glory.
column3: She had tried to find him, her David, and had been shown the dead, and the glory of the dead-all past and gone-her David's glory.

column2: Shown that long, empty gallery resounding with those aged footsteps, and the pictures--pictures--pictures--of men and women who had once been babes like her little son and David's, now dead and gone--not one soul among them all to greet her.
column3: Shown that long, empty gallery resounding with those aged footsteps, and the pictures-pictures-pictures-of men and women who had once been babes like her little son and David's, now dead and gone-not one soul among them all to greet her.

column2: Proud lords and dames in frames of gold; young men and maidens in costly silks and velvets of marvellous dyes, red-cheeked, red-lipped, and soullessly silent; and she, alone and undefended in their midst, holding in her arms their last descendant. All those painted fingers seemed lifted to point at her; those silent red lips parted to cry out at her, "Look at this stranger claiming to be one of us; send her away."
column3: Proud lords and dames in frames of gold; young men and maidens in costly silks and velvets of marvellous dyes, red cheeked, red lipped, and soullessly silent; and she, alone and undefended in their midst, holding in her arms their last descendant. All those painted fingers seemed lifted to point at her; those silent red lips parted to cry out at her, "Look at this stranger claiming to be one of us; send her away."

column2: And David--her David--was one of these!
column3: And David-her David-was one of these!

column2: What they had felt--what they had thought and striven for--was it all intensified and concentrated in him?
column3: What they had felt-what they had thought and striven for-was it all intensified and concentrated in him?

column2: Oh, if her soul could only reach to him, wherever he was, and penetrate this impalpable veil that stretched between them!
column3: Oh, if her soul could only reach to him, wherever he was, and penetrate this impalpable veil that stretched between them!

column2: If her hands could only touch him, her eyes look into his and see what lay in their depths for her!
column3: If her hands could only touch him, her eyes look into his and see what lay in their depths for her!

column2: Then her babe stirred and tossed up his pretty hands, waking her from her sad, vision-seeing trance.
column3: Then her babe stirred and tossed up his pretty hands, waking her from her sad, vision seeing trance.

column2: He opened his large, clear eyes, and suddenly it seemed that her wish was granted,--that the veil was rent and she was looking into David's eyes and seeing his soul free, no longer chained by invisible links to those dead and gone beings, and their traditions.
column3: He opened his large, clear eyes, and suddenly it seemed that her wish was granted,--that the veil was rent and she was looking into David's eyes and seeing his soul free, no longer chained by invisible links to those dead and gone beings, and their traditions.

column2: This had been all a dream--a dream.
column3: This had been all a dream-a dream.

column2: She gathered the child in her arms and held him with his sweet, warm lips pressed to her breast and his soft little hand thrust in her bosom. David's little son--David's little son!
column3: She gathered the child in her arms and held him with his sweet, warm lips pressed to her breast and his soft little hand thrust in her bosom. David's little son-David's little son!

column2: Surely all was good and well with the world!
column3: Surely all was good and well with the world!

column2: Had not evil things been said of David even on her own mountain?

column2: It was the trail of the serpent of ill report.

column2: He had not confided his sacred secret to these people, and they had thought what they pleased.

column2: Surely he had told his mother about his wife.

column2: She would go to his mother and wait for his return, and there she would bring her precious gift--David's little son.

column2: Quickly she packed her few belongings and rang for a messenger, and as she stood an instant waiting for an answer to her ring, the white-capped nurse she had noticed in the morning passed by with the baby in her arms.

column2: Her ring for a messenger had not been answered, and she did not know how to find her husband's country-seat. She felt faint and weary, but did not think of hunger, nor that it was long past the dinner-hour, and that she had eaten nothing since her early breakfast.

column2: Resolutely she closed her door, and dressed her baby carefully; then she arrayed herself in the soft silk gown, and the wide hat with the heavy plume, and then--could David have seen her with her courageous eyes and lifted head, and the faint color from excitement in her cheeks--he would no longer have feared to take her by the hand and lead her to his mother and say, "She is my wife, and the loveliest lady in the land."

column2: People looked at her as she passed, and turned to look again.

column2: Down wide, carpeted stairs she went, until she came to a broad landing with recessed windows, where were round polished tables and people seated, sipping tea and eating thin bread and butter and muffins.
column3: Down wide, carpeted stairs she went, until she came to a broad landing with recessed windows, where were round polished tables and people seated, sipping tea and eating thin bread and butter and muffins.
